How come some have Club Kits but some have country kits? Ik Hazard and 
Gotze situation but for example Neymar has Brazil but Barca is also Nike. 
And ﻿
top_comment.author: Bryan Castellanos

comments.text:
Oh and in case of Neymar they probably just wanted to show diversity :P 
"look we got so many kits!"
comments.author: Yovely

comments.text:
It's because of their advertising: for example FC Barcelona's kits are 
sponsored by Nike, while other clubs get sponsored by Adidas or Puma, so 
you can't obviously use those in a Nike ad. Take Pique and Iniesta for 
example: their club (Barcelona) is sponsored by Nike but the Spanish 
Nationalteam is sponsored by Adidas, that's why they don't wear Spain 
trikots. And then we have people like Götze, who are individually 
sponsored, while neither club nor country kit is from Nike, Götze still 
makes advertisement for Nike shoes. This is why he doesn't wear a specific 
kit but simply black and white. Hope that helped.
comments.author: Yovely

factors for Messi's success.
comments.author: Xiaoshen Wang

comments.text:
+SocaTrain and Ronaldo doesn't have nice teammates that help him to score? 
He doesn't have Benzema or Bale to help him score for Madrid? Stop using 
the superior teamates excuse to rationalize why Messi scores so much, 
because you could say the same exact thing about Ronaldo, even if he is 
more selfish, he still gets assists to score in the first place from world 
class players. Even back in Ronaldo's Man U days, he had Rooney to help him 
and make him look like a stud by supplying him with assists. Messi, even 
with good teammates like Iniesta and Xavi, creates his own chances to score 
with his left foot. The man dribbles full grown man defenders and makes 
them look like amateur bitches all the fucking time and he doesn't use 
stepovers or athleticism like Ronaldo to beat them, he does it with his 
pure ball control which is just too nice. Football is a success driven 
competition, if you succeed and produce and win trophies and honors and 
accolades, you are technically considered the best. That's how it works in 
every sport. That is the one type of standard you can use to judge a player 
against others in an objective manner.

comments.text:
+GLMELEE13 You made me face palm so hard, it is unbelievable. Rugby. Is. 
Not. The. Same. As. American. Football. 

First off, rugby players don't wear the protective padding gear. 
Secondly, rugby players have a correct and incorrect (legal/illegal) way to 
tackle. From my limited knowledge of American football, players just run 
into each other at full speed.
Those are the two main differences.

I do agree with you on calling football soccer. Here in Ireland, we call it 
soccer too, I don't know where Callum Donaghy gets the impression that it's 
called football. We call it soccer for a good reason, we have our own sport 
called football (Aka Gaelic Football). And, you Americans call it soccer 
for a similar reason,  you have a sport you guys call football. Same 
applies to Australians, I think. Aussie rules is referred to as Football as 
far as I know (according to my cousin living there),  So there are plenty 
of reasons for calling soccer soccer.

By the way, for all these people who say "its football! not soccer" 
Soccer is "footballs" nickname, mainly because there was no way to 
distinguish between rugby football and football.
Pretty much the whole world call soccer soccer, excluding European 
countries. 

That is my rant for the day ~
comments.author: Cathal Cummins

comments.text:
+GLMELEE13 Rugby ISN'T American Football thank you very much. Rugby may 
seem to you as not different to American football But it has a lot of 
difference. For instance, Rugby you can't pass forward as a quarterback. 
And u don't wear protection armour. Or as u say "armor". To find out more, 
search the wiki ffs.

comments.text:
+Joe Joiner You are confused. This is not a World Cup ad. It's a Nike ad 
that aired during the World Cup. It takes advantage of the zeal for sport 
and country (as evidenced by the large stadium and the particular kits each 
player is wearing) to market Nike products. Anyone in the marketing 
communications or advertising world understands that this ad is pure gold 
because of the exposure it gets Nike by association to the top 15-20 
footballers in the world. If every advertisement played out as "this is our 
product, here are its features, it costs this much money," every 
advertisement would be in the style of a late-night-only infomercial.

Nike doesn't care as much about selling individual products as it does 
building brand loyalists. Every piece of apparel in the film is made by 
Nike - boots, socks, jackets, shirts, gloves - all of it. By giving the 
viewer a direct link between their broad range of products and the best of 
the best in the most popular sport ever devised by man, they are creating 
an image. "If it's good enough for Eden/Ibra/CR7, it's good enough for 
me..." Some people buy into the image, some don't.
comments.author: JaffinatorGaming

comments.text:
+Joe Joiner It's not a poor marketing effort. It's meant for a certain 
audience. That audience isn't clueless Americans who know nothing about the 
sport. It's for children and teens around the world who dream to be these 
superstars. You can connect with the video and therefore be more willing to 
buy their products. In many ways it's worked.
comments.author: TheNakul707Studios

comments.text:
+Joe Joiner whoa I never realized that they needed to blatantly make it 
obvious for simpletons like yourself. This is a sports ad. Sports people 
(in fact people with at least some semblance of sports knowledge) will 
understand it, they'll know what it's referencing (especially upon the time 
of its release; RIGHT BEFORE THE WORLD CUP). Just because it didn't have 
flashing signs or words saying "WORLD CUP AD RIGHT HERE" doesn't mean it 
wasn't hard to figure out. As I keep trying to say (and I must reiterate) 
the message of "winner stays on" is promoting the ideas of the World Cup. 
You have the superstar footballers playing for their nation, in front of 
thousands of fans, and you honestly don't know who'll go on and who'll walk 
home. Yet it seems like for an ad to be successful it needs to be simple 
and upfront. This and Write the Future are superbly well done as ads, but 
to be fair I would like you to name some ads that were well done. Don't be 
shy obviously you know of some better ones if you can bash this one
comments.author: Lopsided Velociraptor

comments.text:
+Lopsided Velociraptor Ok I'm giving up here because clearly nobody is 
listening to my point. I really couldn't give a shit about whether the 
football "winner stays on" message is good or not. What I was struck by is 
that *THE WORLD CUP IS NOT MENTIONED IN AN AD DEVISED FOR THE WORLD CUP*. I 
don't think I can dumb it down more than that.

No, I don't like football, but that's not the point! I'm *not slating the 
football or the nostalgic message*. I just couldn't decipher what the ad 
was about after watching it, therefore it doesn't serve it's purpose.
comments.author: Joe Joiner

comments.text:
+Joe Joiner lmfao "I've lost faith in humanity" clearly you didn't like

Now obviously you aren't a football fan (which is okay) but don't go saying

comments.author: Devean Atkinson

comments.text:
+Lopsided Velociraptor I was watching this video because it was one of the 
most popular of this year, so was promoted on the YouTube Rewind 2014 
channel. I understand that it's very nostalgic and people enjoy football. I 
get that, but that's not my point. My point is the advertisement does not 
achieve its primary goal; to advertise the product. By very definition, an 
advert and a marketing campaign as a whole should show off the product—in 
this case the World Cup—to potential consumers and give them good reason to 
buy into it. This ad doesn't display the World Cup logo anywhere, doesn't 
mention World Cup in the video title/description, or give any real 
clarification as to what it's advertising to those who are unfamiliar. I 
shouldn't have to do research. I should be able to garner exactly what it 
is from the initial viewing.
comments.author: Joe Joiner

that's happened in this world is because of the united states or us poking 
our affairs and being nosy in foreign affairs. If I could, I would move 
from this country....I heard most people in Canada leave their doors! WHY? 
Because there is no crime there! Why do we have it here? Hmmmm....I wonder!

countries around the world is ridiculous. We don't have an official

top_comment.text:
If you think this is a commercial, you're wrong.
It is actually cinema, a story arc so well told, filmed and played that it 
should be "Oscar" material.
This little short conveys EXACTLY how I felt as a kid.
With my early abilities for the sport inversely proportional to this later 
age absolute passion for it, I was systematically one of the last "players" 
to be picked-up for any street soccer team.
Still, it didn't matter because, as soon as I touched the ball, I was one 
the idols from my trading cards collection and the convenient street 
cul-de-sac where we played became the largest, most attended stadium I 
could dream of.﻿
